# Hierarchies, slashes, and colons

This is lame and nerdy but I've always wondered why some systems use `/` to denote hierarchy whereas others use `:`. For example, filesystems usually use slashes like `/home/user/over/the/rainbow`, whereas URNs look like `urn:isbn:0451450523`.

Is there a meaningful difference between the two?

The [SSB URI scheme](%g3hPVPDEO1Aj/uPl0+J2NlhFB2bbFLIHlty+YuqFZ3w=.sha256) uses colons, like a URN, but I recently noticed [a post on message types](%efu2OHVS38D3BSD4iZATM5sg/jdxBPPNTzc65wjqbkE=.sha256) that used slashes in the example (which look like [media types](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_type#Common_examples)).

I've tried searching the web for this but haven't been able to figure out why or how these symbols are used. To make things more complex, programming languages often use both `.` and `:`:

```js
a.b.c = { d: { e: { f: {} } } }
```
